stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the final main course (Course 15), refining a spaceship interior and redesigning the level's boss fight based on live feedback from his chat. He then begins the planning phase for the course's 'retro section', a medley of iconic areas from the original Super Mario 64, which involves recovering old assets with help from his community.

development_findings.summary: The project is nearing a major milestone: the completion of all main courses. After Course 15 is finished, the team will move on to polishing.
development_findings.quote: After that we have one more sub area to do in course 15. And we're finally done. Oh my God, dude, all the main courses will be finished.

development_findings.summary: The boss arena for Course 15 was redesigned mid-stream from a static factory to a dynamic planet that the boss destroys, based on a viewer's suggestion that Kaze preferred both aesthetically and technically.
development_findings.quote: That would also be lower poly than my whole stupid factory here. And I hate that I have this whole factory here actually... Planet is cooler.

development_findings.summary: The team faces technical limitations of the N64, such as optimizing fields of plants by making them a single object to manage rendering costs.
development_findings.quote: We can't make every individual strand an object, because that's way too expensive to render.

development_findings.summary: The project includes contributions from guest level designers, such as Hazer, whose pastel-colored level was shown on stream.
development_findings.quote: This is what he's planned for this game. Very pastel color, very Yoshi's Island, and that's why I like it.

development_findings.summary: Ongoing engine development frequently breaks older levels, but Kaze considers this a normal part of the process and is confident in his ability to fix the issues.
development_findings.quote: This is what happens when you keep changing the engine, all the levels just break. I'm not worried about it, it's gonna be easy to fix.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is planning a 'retro section' for Course 15 that will be a medley of iconic areas from the original Super Mario 64, stitched together as floating islands.
A rare but known bug exists where performing a Backwards Long Jump (BLJ) can crash the game, which Kaze acknowledges needs to be fixed.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, there's the crash. And now the whole game's gone too bad.

development_findings.summary: The game's ROM size is currently 58.8 MB, comfortably under the self-imposed 64 MB limit.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong design philosophy against including numerous options, believing it complicates development and degrades the user experience.
context_findings.quote: People always ask for more and more and if I added everyone's request for options, I would have an option menu with 260 items and it would be shit like switch to old cap block texture.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's policy on sharing his work is that others are free to use his assets, but only if they can figure out how to implement them without his support.
context_findings.quote: If you are able to use my stuff without my help, then you're free to use it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is willing to change design elements based on feedback, such as altering a boss's appearance from growing tumors to mushrooms to make it less 'disgusting' and 'traumatizing'.
context_findings.quote: At first I had him grow tumors. And I showed this to someone and they said this is way too disgusting. So I changed the tumors into mushrooms that grow out of the Yoshi.

context_findings.summary: A core part of Kaze's level design philosophy is to show the player a goal, like a star, early on but make it inaccessible until later to build anticipation.
context_findings.quote: It's very important to constantly edge the player.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions his personal life, including that he has a baby and his parents are coming to visit, indicating the balance between his work and family life.
context_findings.quote: My parents are coming tomorrow to look at the baby. I'm not prepared to have so many people here.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels he has received most of the useful feedback from the demo and now finds new feedback to be less actionable.
context_findings.quote: A lot of the feedback I'm getting now is like either super nitpicky or contradicting another feedback I got, so I can't really do anything about that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze hires someone to create YouTube shorts for his channel for $5 per short, and is amused by their 'mobile game ad' style.

biobak.summary: Kaze acknowledges Biobak's artistic feedback on his UV mapping, showing a collaborative and respectful dynamic.
biobak.quote: I know Biobak. I'm still a newbie artist, you know how it is.

biobak.summary: Kaze anticipates that Biobak, the graphics artist, will have further changes to the boss model, so he is holding off on final implementation.
biobak.quote: I purposefully did not fully import it yet because I figured Biobak had changes to it.

badub.summary: Kaze plans to suggest a community idea to Badub for the music in the Mario 64 retro section, implying Badub has creative freedom over the soundtrack.
badub.quote: Oh, I can suggest it to Badub, but maybe he has a good idea with it.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for animating the 'baby Yoshi' enemies that the boss spawns during its fight.
zeina.quote: Zayna's currently animating them. So hopefully they will be better once they are animated.

zeina.summary: Kaze casually refers to Zeina as his wife during the stream, confirming their personal and professional relationship.
zeina.quote: My wife must be doing something weird.

key_stories.title: Boss Arena Planet Concept
key_stories.summary: Unhappy with his 'stupid factory' concept for a boss arena, Kaze adopted a viewer's suggestion to have the fight occur on a planet that the boss dramatically destroys. This collaborative moment led to a solution that Kaze found more exciting and technically superior.
key_stories.challenge: The planned boss arena for Course 15 was a static factory concept that Kaze felt was uninspired and technically inefficient.
key_stories.process: During the stream, a viewer suggested the boss fight should take place on a small planet which the boss then destroys. Kaze and the chat collectively workshopped the idea, imagining the boss drilling into the planet like a Beyblade, causing it to break apart.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze fully embraced the new planet concept, immediately began brainstorming implementation details, and decided it was a superior direction for the boss fight both creatively and technically.
key_stories.key_quote: That would also be lower poly than my whole stupid factory here. And I hate that I have this whole factory here actually. It says please make it more interesting too but like, no, no, no, we don't need the factory. Planet is cooler.

key_stories.title: Recovering Mario 64 Level Assets
key_stories.summary: Kaze was blocked from working on a retro-themed level because his required assets were in an incompatible file format. After a humorous failure with an online tool, a member of his Discord community stepped in to convert the files, demonstrating the project's reliance on community support.
key_stories.challenge: To build the Mario 64-themed retro level, Kaze needed the original game's level geometry, but his archived files were in the unusable .skp (Sketchup) format, and he did not want to install the required software.
key_stories.process: Kaze first attempted to use a free online file converter, which failed after comically forcing him to play a game of Tetris. He then asked for help in his Discord server, and a user named HooliKaleb offered to perform the conversion for him.
key_stories.outcome: The community member successfully converted the files to the .obj format and sent them back, unblocking development and allowing Kaze to immediately begin planning the layout of the retro level with the actual assets.
key_stories.key_quote: You're fucking kidding me. It's an skp file. No! Why is it a .skp file? I hate 2018.

open_questions.topic: Final Boss Concept and Story Integration
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that the final boss should be connected to the story of what the Yoshis were forced to build for Bowser. He briefly considered and dismissed a Bowser mech and a 'Boshi' concept.
questions: What are the current leading ideas for the final boss?
How is the game's narrative influencing the design of the final encounter?
Besides the boss itself, what other story elements are you hoping to resolve in the finale?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that guest developers Hazer and Martiste are contributing levels. He showed a brief clip of Hazer's pastel-colored level.
questions: How did the collaborations with guest level designers like Hazer and Martiste come about?
What creative freedom or constraints do you give to guest contributors?
How do you plan to integrate these guest levels into the overall game progression?

open_questions.context: Kaze has made significant changes to Mario's physics and controls compared to the vanilla game, and firmly stated he will not add an option to revert to the original controls.
questions: What was the core design philosophy behind overhauling Mario's moveset?
Could you walk through the decision to remove a move as iconic as the dive and replace it with the 'grandpa dive'?
How do you balance making the controls feel fresh and new with the muscle memory players have from the original game?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that engine changes often break older levels, but that he is not worried because they are 'easy to fix'.
questions: Can you describe the process of fixing an old level after a major engine update?
What are the most common things that break when you update the engine?
How does the decompilation project base help or hinder this process of constant iteration?
